sect1.title: Prerequisite Software
sect1.para: OpenACS requires, at a minimum, an operating system, database, and webserver to work. Many additional programs, such as a build environment, Mail Transport Agent, and source control system, are also needed for a fully effective installation.

The OpenACS installation instructions assume the operating system and build environment are installed. The instructions explain installation of Tcl, Tcllib, tDOM, tclwebtest, a Web Server, a Database, a Process Controller, and Source Control software. The following external links are for reference only.

formalpara.para: The OpenACS tarball comprises the core packages and many useful additional packages. This includes a full set of documentation. The tarball works with both PostgreSQL and Oracle. Some scripts require bash shell.

formalpara.title: Operating System
formalpara.para: OpenACS is designed for a Unix-like system. It is developed primarily in Linux. It can be run on Mac OS X, and in Windows within VMWare.

formalpara.title: GNU/Linux
formalpara.para: The installation assumes a linux kernel of 2.2.22 or newer, or 2.4.14 or newer.

formalpara.title: FreeBSD
formalpara.para: FreeBSD guide. The OpenACS Reference Platform uses shell scripts written for bash, which is the standard Linux shell. If you are using a different shell, you will need to substitute your shell's conventions for setting environment variables when appropriate, and install bash to work with the scripts. Substitute fetch when the instructions suggest you use wget to download software.

formalpara.title: Windows/VMWare
formalpara.para: The only way to run OpenACS on Windows is through the VMWare emulator. (Please let me know if you have OpenACS running directly in Windows.)

formalpara.title: Build Environment
formalpara.para: The Reference Platform installation compiles most programs from source code.

formalpara.title: glibc 2.2 or newer, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: You need recent versions of these libraries for Oracle to work properly. For Unicode support, you need glibc 2.2 or newer. This should be included in your operating system distribution.

formalpara.title: GNU Make 3.76.1 or newer, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: PostgreSQL and AOLserver require gmake to compile. Note that on most linux distributions, GNU Make is simply named make and there is no gmake, whereas on BSD distributions, make and gmake are different --use gmake.

formalpara.title: Tcl 8.5.x, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: OpenACS is written in Tcl, an interpreted language. A threaded version of the Tcl interpreter must be installed for OpenACS to work. The Tcl interpreter that is included in most standard distributions may not be thread safe.

formalpara.title: Tcl 8.5.x development headers and libraries, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: The site-wide-search service, OpenFTS, requires these to compile. (Debian users: apt-get install tcl8.5-dev). You need this to install OpenFTS.

formalpara.title: Tcllib, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: OpenACS &version; uses those Tcl extensions to send e-mail out, among others.

formalpara.title: tDOM, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: OpenACS &version; stores queries in XML files, so we use an AOLserver module called tDOM to parse these files. (This replaces libxml2, which was used prior to 4.6.4.)

formalpara.title: tclwebtest, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: tclwebtest is a tool for testing web interfaces via Tcl scripts.

formalpara.title: Web Server
formalpara.para: The web server handles incoming HTTP requests, provides a runtime environment for OpenACS's Tcl code, connects to the database, sends out HTTP responses, and logs requests and errors. OpenACS uses AOLserver; some people have had success running Apache with mod_nsd.

formalpara.title: AOLserver 4.x, REQUIRED
formalpara.para: Provides the base HTTP server

listitem.para: Mat Kovach is graciously maintaining an AOLserver distribution that includes all the patches and modules needed to run OpenACS &version;. These instructions will describe how to install using his source distribution. He also has binaries for SuSE 7.3 and OpenBSD 2.8 (and perhaps more to come), currently located at uptime.openacs.org.
It's also possible to download all the pieces and patches yourself:

The OpenACS PostgreSQL driver (nspostgres.so) is available from SourceForge. If you do decide to use nspostgres.so, you have to remember to change the AOLserver config file to point to nspostgres.so instead of postgres.so. This guide uses Mat Kovach's distro (i.e. postgres.so)
The patch that makes exec work on BSD is available at sourceforge.net
The patch for AOLserver 3.x that makes ns_uuencode work for binary files is available at sourceforge.net
The patch that makes AOLserver 3.x respect the -g flag is available at sourceforge.net

formalpara.title: nsopenssl, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: Provides SSL capabilities for AOLserver. It requires OpenSSL. You need this if you want users to make secure (https) connections to your webserver. aolserver3.x requires nsopenssl 2.1a. aolserver4.x requires nsopenssl3; see aolserver.com for latest release. (home page)

formalpara.title: ns_pam 0.1 or newer, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: Provides PAM capabilities for AOLserver. You need this if you want OpenACS users to authenticate through a PAM module (such as RADIUS).

formalpara.title: pam_radius 1.3.16, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: Provides RADIUS capabilities for PAM. You need this if you want to use RADIUS authentication via PAM in OpenACS.

formalpara.title: ns_ldap 0.r8, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: Provides LDAP capabilities for AOLserver. You need this if you want to use LDAP authentication in OpenACS.

formalpara.title: OpenFTS Tcl 0.3.2, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: Adds full-text-search to PostgreSQL and includes a driver for AOLserver. You need this if you want users to be able to search for any text on your site. For postgres 7.4.x and higher, full text search is also available via tsearch2.

formalpara.title: Analog 5.32 or newer, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: This program examines web server request logs, looks up DNS values, and produces a report. You need this if you want to see how much traffic your site is getting.

formalpara.title: Balance 3.11 or newer, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: "Balance is a simple but powerful generic tcp proxy with round robin load balancing and failover mechanisms." You need this or something equivalent if you are running a high-availability production site and do not have an external load balancing system.

formalpara.title: Database
formalpara.para: The data on your site (for example, user names and passwords, calender entries, and notes) is stored in the database. OpenACS separates the database with an abstraction layer, which means that several different databases all function identically. While you can run the core OpenACS on any supported database, not all contributed packages support all databases.

formalpara.title: Oracle 8.1.7 (Either this or PostgreSQL is REQUIRED)
formalpara.para: You can register and download Oracle from Oracle TechNet. You need this if you want to use an Oracle database.

formalpara.title: PostgreSQL 7.4.x (Either this or Oracle is REQUIRED)
formalpara.para: You need this if you want to use a PostgreSQL database.

formalpara.title: Process Controller
formalpara.para: This is software that initiates other software, and restarts that software if it fails. On Linux, we recommend using Daemontools to control AOLserver and qmail.

formalpara.title: Daemontools 0.76, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: You need this if you want AOLserver and qmail to run "supervised," meaning that they are monitored and automatically restarted if they fail. An alternative would be to run the services from inittab.

formalpara.title: Mail Transport Agent
formalpara.para: A Mail Transport Agent is a program that handles all incoming and outgoing mail. The Reference Platform uses Qmail; any MTA that provides a sendmail wrapper (that is, that can be invoked by calling the sendmail program with the same variables that sendmail expects) can be used.

formalpara.title: Netqmail 1.04, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: You need this (or a different Mail Transport Agent) if you want your webserver to send and receive email.

formalpara.title: ucspi-tcp 0.88, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: This program listens for incoming TCP connections and hands them to a program. We use it instead of inetd, which is insecure. You need this if you are running qmail.

formalpara.title: DocBook, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: (docbook-xml v4.4, docbook-xsl v1.56, libxslt 1.0.21, xsltproc 1.0.21). You need this to write or edit documentation.

formalpara.title: Source Control
formalpara.para: A Source Control system keeps track of all of the old versions of your files. It lets you recover old files, compare versions of file, and identify specific versions of files. You can use any source control system; the Reference Platform and the OpenACS.org repository (where you can get patched and development code in between releases) use cvs.

formalpara.title: cvs 1.11.18, OPTIONAL
formalpara.para: cvs is included in most unix distributions. You need this if you want to track old versions of your files, do controlled deployment of code from development to production, or get or contribute development code from openacs.org.
